item.title: Trust Your Team by Default
item.description: Trust is the foundation of high-performing teams. If you can’t trust them, no amount of control will ever be enough.

item.title: Stop Worshipping the 10x Dev
item.description: The most dangerous developer on your team might be your “best” one.

item.title: Optimize for Humans
item.description: If your code confuses people, is is really optimized?

item.title: Legacy is Yesterday's Clean Code
item.description: We love to hate the devs who came before us — forgetting we’re next in line.

item.title: Avoid Dotted Lines in Your Monolith
item.description: Half-measures in code charge interest you never agreed to pay.

item.title: Embracing The Impostor Syndrome
item.description: During my early career, I was often the most skilled, or most experienced tech guy in the room. But as I learned later in life, that was a bad thing for my career progression.

item.title: Why You Should Be Commenting Your Code
item.description: Many developers shun inline comments because they don’t understand when and where they are useful. They are missing out on incredible value.

item.title: On houses, debt and software rewrites
item.description: Most non-developers struggle to understand the need for software refactoring. Imagine if you were constantly rebuilding your house.
